recipes.title: Sassafras Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: A unique jelly made from strong sassafras tea.

instructions.text: Boil two cups strong sassafras tea and one package powdered pectin.
Add three cups strained honey.
Strain and put in jars.

recipes.title: Rhubarb Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: A tangy jelly made from fresh rhubarb.

instructions.text: Wash and slice three pounds rhubarb.
Add one cup water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer ten minutes.
Strain through cheesecloth.
Add three pounds of sugar (about seven cups) and bring to a rolling boil.
Add one bottle liquid pectin.
Cook, stirring, one more minute.
Pour in glasses. Jelly should harden in three to four hours.

recipes.title: Poke Pickles
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian pickles from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Pickled young poke stalks, preserved in spiced vinegar.

instructions.text: Collect very young stalks, scrape, remove leaves, and pack in jars.
Combine one cup vinegar, half cup sugar, one tablespoon salt, one stick cinnamon, several whole cloves.
Boil, pour over poke, and seal.

recipes.title: Pickled Pussley
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian pickles from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Pickled purslane tips in mustard vinegar.

instructions.text: Cook wild onions with vinegar and one-quarter cup ground mustard seed.
Simmer, strain.
Pour over pussley tips.

recipes.title: Blackberry Syrup
recipes.description: A spiced blackberry syrup for pancakes.

instructions.text: Mix all ingredients together.
Boil for fifteen minutes.
Use over pancakes.

recipes.title: Blackberry Jelly
recipes.description: Simple blackberry jelly made without commercial pectin.

instructions.text: Crush one quart berries in a pan without sugar or water.
Cook slowly eight minutes.
Strain; measure; bring to boiling point.
Add 1 1/2 cups sugar to each cup juice gradually, so the boiling does not stop.
Bring to a brisk boil, skim, and bottle.

notes: No commercial pectin needed - natural pectin in berries

recipes.title: Sumac and Elderberry Jelly
recipes.description: A unique jelly combining tart sumac with sweet elderberries.

instructions.text: Boil one pint sumac berries in three pints water.
Add one pint elderberries.
Strain through cloth.
Add one cup sugar for each cup juice and cook into jelly.

recipes.title: Elderberry Jelly
recipes.description: Classic elderberry jelly.

instructions.text: Cook elderberries with a small amount of water until thoroughly cooked.
Strain, and to one pint juice, add one pound sugar.
Cook until it jellies.

recipes.title: Spiced Elderberries
recipes.description: Spiced preserved elderberries.

instructions.text: Wash elderberries and pack in self-sealing jars with a half teaspoon each of cloves and allspice.
Cover with vinegar.
Boil one cup of sugar and pour over the berries.
Seal while hot.

recipes.title: Wild Strawberry Jam
recipes.description: Jam from tiny wild strawberries. As they say, 'If it is four o'clock by the time you get your clothes on, it will be light enough to pick strawberries.'

instructions.text: Put a quart of berries in a pot, add a cup of sugar, and bring to a boil, stirring gently.
Boil three minutes, add another cup of sugar and boil three more minutes.
Add a final cup of sugar, skim off foam and put in jars and seal.

notes: Wild strawberries are rich in iron and vitamin C

recipes.title: Wild Strawberry Preserves
recipes.description: Old-fashioned strawberry preserves that rest overnight.

instructions.text: To a quart of strawberries, add one cup of sugar and three tablespoons water.
Boil slowly fifteen minutes. Let stand overnight.
Next morning, bring to boiling point and pour in jars while hot.

recipes.title: Strawberry Leather
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian fruit leather from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: Sun-dried strawberry leather, rolled up like a jelly cake.

instructions.text: Mash ripe berries to pulp.
Spread on platters.
When dry, dust with sugar and roll up like a jelly cake into pieces.
Pack into clean jars.

notes: A traditional method of preserving fruit before glass jars were available

recipes.title: Canned Wild Greens
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian canning method from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: How to can wild greens for winter use.

instructions.text: Mix mustard and wild turnip greens, or buff sallet and mustard mixed, or with creases.
Fix and precook until tender.
Put in jars, add water, seal.
Cook thirty minutes in pressure cooker.

notes: Most wild sallets can be canned this way

recipes.title: Candied Persimmons
recipes.description: Persimmons preserved with sugar until candied.

instructions.text: Pack persimmons in jars, alternating with layers of sugar.
Put on lids and store in a cool place until they become candied.

recipes.title: Persimmon Butter
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian fruit butter from Foxfire 3
recipes.description: A spiced persimmon spread like apple butter.

instructions.text: Cook and strain persimmons.
Add 1/2 teaspoon soda to each cup pulp.
Sweeten and flavor with spices or orange rind.
Cook thoroughly and bottle.

recipes.title: Wild Plum Conserve
recipes.description: A rich conserve with plums, oranges, and raisins.

instructions.text: Wash and pick over plums. Cover with boiling water, and add 1/2 teaspoon soda.
Bring to rolling boil. Pour off the soda water, rinse plums, and strain through a colander.
Slice oranges in thin slices, rind and all, removing seeds, and grind the raisins.
Combine fruit and sugar, adding enough water to keep them from sticking.
Simmer until thick and clear.

recipes.title: Wild Plum Jelly
recipes.description: Classic wild plum jelly.

instructions.text: Cover 1/2 gallon half-ripe plums with water in a porcelain kettle.
Boil ten minutes.
Pour off the juice and strain through flannel.
Add one pound sugar to each pint juice.
Boil until it will harden when cold (about twenty to thirty minutes).

notes: Use half-ripe plums for best jelling

recipes.title: Elderberry-Apple-Orange Jam
recipes.description: A complex jam combining elderberries with apples and citrus.

instructions.text: Cook apples until mushy.
Add the berries, oranges, and lemon chopped fine.
Add sugar and cook until thick.

recipes.title: Spiced Grapes
recipes.description: Pickled spiced grapes.

instructions.text: Stem and wash five pounds grapes.
Boil one and one-half pints of good apple vinegar with sugar and one stick cinnamon and half teaspoon allspice.
Add grapes and boil until thick.
Bottle and seal while hot.

recipes.title: Mayapple Marmalade
recipes.description: A marmalade from ripe mayapple fruits with their strawberry-like flavor.

instructions.text: Gather ripe fruits and simmer until soft.
Strain through a colander.
Boil the pulp with sugar to taste.

notes: CAUTION: Only the ripe fruit is edible - all other parts of the plant are poisonous
Green mayapples can cause stomach ache

flags: Only ripe fruit is safe - rest of plant is poisonous

recipes.title: Groundcherry Preserves
recipes.description: Preserves made from groundcherries (husk tomatoes).

instructions.text: Remove husks from groundcherries and wash.
Combine with sugar, water, and lemon juice.
Cook slowly until thick.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Also called cape gooseberry or husk tomato

recipes.title: Pickled Walnuts
recipes.description: Green walnuts pickled in spiced vinegar.

instructions.text: Gather green walnuts before the shell hardens (test with a needle).
Soak in brine for nine days, changing brine every three days.
Drain and spread on trays in sun until they turn black.
Pack in jars.
Boil vinegar with spices and pour over walnuts.
Seal and store.

notes: Must use young green walnuts before shell hardens

recipes.title: Icicle Pickles
recipes.description: Sweet, crisp cucumber pickles that take about two weeks to make.

instructions.text: Split cucumbers lengthwise, no matter how small. Add salt to boiling water and pour over cucumbers. Let stand one week.
Drain, cover with boiling water again and let stand twenty-four hours.
Drain, dissolve alum in boiling water and pour over pickles. Let stand twenty-four hours.
Drain. Boil vinegar, sugar, and all spices together and pour over pickles.
Do this for four mornings - pouring off liquid, reboiling it, and pouring back over pickles boiling hot.
Seal in cans.

notes: Will also keep in an open jar but most people seal them for winter

recipes.title: Lime Pickles
recipes.description: Crisp pickles made with builder's lime for extra crunch.

instructions.text: Let tomatoes or cucumbers soak with lime and water for twenty-four hours.
Then let pickles soak in clear water for four hours, changing water every hour.
Make syrup of vinegar, sugar, and pickling spice and bring to a boil.
Add cucumbers and let stand overnight.
Boil for one hour, pack in glass jars, and seal.

recipes.title: Spiced Grapes Relish
recipes.description: A spiced grape relish used with meat and bread.

instructions.text: Wash, stem, and pulp grapes.
Put pulp with seeds over fire and cook until seeds come free.
Add skins and pulp together, and also add sugar, vinegar, and spices.
Cook until thick and can.

recipes.title: Pickled Green Tomatoes
recipes.description: Hot and sweet pickled green tomatoes.

instructions.text: Wash and quarter green tomatoes. Pack raw into pint jars.
Add to each jar two-three small whole pods of hot pepper and one quartered pod of bell pepper.
Make brine of two parts vinegar, one part water, one part sugar; heat until sugar melts.
Pour into packed jars leaving half-inch at top.
Put on lids and rings and process fifteen minutes in water bath.

recipes.title: Pickled Peaches or Apples
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian pickled fruit from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: Spiced pickled peaches or apples.

instructions.text: Peel apples or peaches, quarter, and put in a pot.
Make enough brine of two parts vinegar, two parts sugar, and one part water to cover fruit.
Add ground cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice to taste, and cook until tender.
When done, lift fruit out and pack into jars.
Keep brine simmering and pour into jars over fruit leaving one-half inch at top.
Seal immediately.

recipes.title: Pepper Sauce (Hot Pepper Relish)
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian hot pepper sauce from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: A hot pepper and onion relish.

instructions.text: Chop onions and peppers up fine.
Pour boiling water over them and let stand for five minutes, then drain.
Put back in kettle and pour on more boiling water, let boil two minutes, drain.
Put back in kettle again.
Add vinegar, sugar, and salt and boil for fifteen minutes.
Can while hot.

recipes.title: Mint Jelly
recipes.description: Fresh mint jelly, traditionally served with lamb.

instructions.text: Do not boil leaves, but pour boiling water over them and let steep.
Strain.
Add sugar and pectin.
Cook until it jells.

recipes.title: Mint Vinegar
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian flavored vinegar from Foxfire 3
recipes.description: Mint-infused vinegar that ripens over several weeks.

instructions.text: Let mint stand covered by sugar for five minutes.
Bring vinegar to a boil.
Add mint and sugar to vinegar and boil three minutes.
Strain through cheesecloth and bottle.
Let stand several weeks to ripen.

recipes.title: Fig Preserves
recipes.description: Simple fig preserves.

instructions.text: Put figs in a pan, and add sugar until it covers the figs.
Let stand overnight.
In the morning, cook until thick and clear.
Put in jars and seal.

notes: Figs should be picked in early morning

recipes.title: Crabapple Jelly
recipes.description: Classic crabapple jelly, can add mint leaves if desired.

instructions.text: Simmer crabapples twenty minutes. Mash in pan.
Strain. Add one cup sugar to one cup juice.
Add mint leaves if desired.
Put in jars, and set in a dark place to thicken.

notes: Crabapples were often added to blackberries or blueberries to help jelly set

recipes.title: Crabapple Butter
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian fruit butter from Foxfire 3
recipes.description: A spiced crabapple butter.

instructions.text: Cook crabapples with peelings and run through a food mill.
Boil slowly until thick.
Add sugar and spices and cook until thick.
Pour into jars and seal.

recipes.title: Sweet Pickled Crabapples
recipes.description: Spiced pickled crabapples.

instructions.text: Wash crabapples. Cut out blossom ends, but leave stems intact.
Combine sugar, spices, vinegar, and water in large saucepan and heat until sugar dissolves.
Add crabapples and simmer gently until tender.
Pack in jars, pour syrup over, and seal.

recipes.title: Possum Haw Jelly
recipes.description: Jelly from possum haw berries, often combined with crabapples.

instructions.text: Boil berries until soft.
Strain through cloth.
Add sugar to taste.
Boil again until thickened.
Combine with crabapples if desired.

notes: Haw berries are extremely seedy

recipes.title: Red Haw (Hawthorn) Relish
recipes.description: A spiced relish from hawthorn fruits.

instructions.text: Crush three pounds fruit (not too ripe).
Add four cups water and cook until soft.
Strain through cloth.
Add sugar, vinegar, and spices.
Boil until thick. Bottle and seal.

recipes.title: Haw Marmalade
recipes.description: A marmalade from hawthorn fruits.

instructions.text: Cook haws in very little water.
Press through a colander to remove seeds.
Add sugar to taste.
Cook until thick and bottle.

recipes.title: Pearl's Sassafras Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian sassafras jelly recipe from Foxfire Book 4
recipes.description: A unique jelly made from sassafras tea, capturing the distinctive flavor of this Appalachian root.

ingredients.prep_note: made by boiling 4 roots in 1 gallon water for 15-20 minutes

instructions.text: Make sassafras tea: Boil 4 average-sized sassafras roots in 1 gallon of water for 15-20 minutes. The longer boiled, the stronger the tea. Strain.
Mix one package of Sure-Jell with 8 cups of sassafras tea in a large saucepan.
Bring quickly to a hard boil, stirring occasionally.
Add 8 cups sugar and bring to a full rolling boil.
Boil hard one minute, stirring constantly.
Skim off foam with a metal spoon.
Pour at once into jelly jars and seal with paraffin.

notes: Pearl also makes sassafras tea, serving it hot or iced, sweetened with sugar or honey.
Sassafras tea can be made stronger or weaker by adjusting boiling time.

recipes.title: Violet Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional wild food recipe from Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: A delicate jelly made from wild violet flowers.

instructions.text: Cook violet flowers with boiling water.
Strain the liquid.
Add sugar, pectin, and juice of half a lemon.
Simmer until it jells.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Violet flowers give this jelly a beautiful color and delicate flavor.

recipes.title: Violet Syrup
recipes.source_note: Traditional cold remedy from Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: A medicinal syrup made from violet blossoms, good for colds or coughs.

instructions.text: Cover violet blossoms with water.
Let stand two days.
Strain the liquid.
Cook with honey and juice of lemon.
Stir well and bring to a boil.
Put in jars and seal.

notes: Good for colds or coughs.

recipes.title: Wild Garlic Vinegar
recipes.description: Infused vinegar made with wild garlic bulbs.

instructions.text: Peel garlic bulbs.
Place in one pint vinegar.
Cover tightly and let stand for ten to fourteen days.
Strain and bottle.

recipes.title: Raspberry Pickles
recipes.description: Spiced pickled raspberries preserved in sweetened vinegar.

instructions.text: Wash 1/2 gallon fresh, almost ripe berries.
Place them in self-sealing jars with a half teaspoon each of cloves and allspice, and one stick of cinnamon.
Boil 1 1/2 pints of good apple vinegar with a half cup of sugar.
Pour over the berries.
Seal while hot.

recipes.title: Raspberry Vinegar
recipes.description: Sweetened raspberry-infused vinegar, a traditional Appalachian condiment.

instructions.text: Put two gallons ripe raspberries in a stone jar.
Pour a gallon cider vinegar over them and let stand twenty-four hours.
Drain, then pour the liquor over a gallon fresh berries and let stand overnight.
Strain and add one measure of sugar for every measure of juice.
Boil and skim.
Bottle when cold.

recipes.title: Sumac and Elderberry Jelly
recipes.description: Unique jelly combining wild sumac berries and elderberries.

instructions.text: Boil one pint sumac berries in three pints water until there is one quart juice.
Separately, boil one quart elderberries in three pints water until fruit is soft.
Mash the elderberries.
Strain juice from both through a thick white cloth.
Mix the juices together.
Add one cup sugar for each cup juice and cook into jelly.

recipes.title: Elderberry Jam
recipes.description: Simple jam made from wild elderberries with vinegar.

instructions.text: Crush and measure the berries.
Add sugar and vinegar.
Boil until thick.
Pour boiling into scalded jars and seal.

recipes.title: Elderberry-Apple-Orange Jam
recipes.description: Rich jam combining elderberries with apples and citrus.

instructions.text: Cook apples until mushy.
Add the berries, oranges, and lemon chopped fine.
Grate the rinds of one orange and the lemon.
Mix together with sugar.
Boil thirty minutes.
Pour into sterilized jars and seal.

recipes.title: Dandelion Blossom Syrup
recipes.description: Honey-like syrup made from dandelion blossoms.

instructions.text: Place blossoms and water in pot.
Bring just to boil, turn off heat, cover, and let sit overnight.
The next day, strain and press liquid from spent flowers.
Add sugar and citrus, then heat slowly, stirring occasionally.
Continue for several hours until reduced to thick, honey-like consistency.
Can in half-pint or pint jars.

recipes.title: Kudzu Blossom Jelly
recipes.description: Purple jelly made from kudzu blossoms.

instructions.text: Wash blossoms and place in a large bowl.
Pour boiling water over blossoms; refrigerate 8 hours or overnight.
Strain blossoms and liquid through colander into Dutch oven.
Add lemon juice and pectin; bring to rolling boil over high heat, stirring constantly.
Stir in sugar; return to rolling boil and boil 1 minute while stirring.
Remove from heat; skim foam with spoon.
Pour into sterilized jars, filling to 1/4 inch from top.
Process in boiling water bath for 5 minutes.

recipes.title: Beautyberry Jelly
recipes.description: Purple jelly made from American beautyberries.

instructions.text: Wash and clean beautyberries, removing all green stems and leaves.
Cover berries with 2 quarts water.
Boil for 20 minutes.
Strain to create infusion.
Use 3 cups of the infusion and bring to boil.
Add Sure-Jell and sugar.
Return to second boil and boil for 2 minutes.
Remove from heat and let stand until foam forms.
Skim off foam.
Pour into sterilized jars and cap.

recipes.title: Loquat Jelly
recipes.description: Clear jelly made from loquat fruit.

instructions.text: Wash loquats, remove seeds and blossom ends.
Barely cover with cold water. Simmer covered 15 minutes until soft.
Strain through jelly bag.
Measure 3 1/2 cups juice and lemon juice.
Add pectin, stir well. Bring to boil, stirring constantly.
Add sugar, return to rolling boil for exactly 2 minutes.
Remove from heat, skim.
Pour into sterilized glasses, seal with paraffin.

recipes.title: Spiced Loquats
recipes.description: Pickled loquats with warm spices.

instructions.text: Wash loquats, remove stem and blossom ends.
Combine sugar, water, and vinegar.
Tie spices in cheesecloth, add to mixture. Boil 10 minutes.
Add fruit, cook gently until tender.
Remove fruit, pour syrup into sterilized jars, fill with hot syrup.
Seal immediately.

recipes.title: Mulberry Vinegar
recipes.description: Fruit vinegar made from mulberries.

instructions.text: Place mulberries in large bowl.
Mash berries and pour hot vinegar over them.
Cover with towel; stir with wooden spoon daily for 3 days.
Strain juice through jelly bag.
Add 1 cup sugar per cup juice.
Boil together for 5 minutes.
Pour into sterilized jars and seal.
To serve: Mix 2 tablespoons vinegar in 8-ounce glass with water and ice.

recipes.title: Mulberry Sauce
recipes.description: Spiced fruit sauce from mulberries.

instructions.text: Add sugar and spices to mashed berries.
Bring to boil.
Simmer until thick, stirring frequently.
Bottle and seal.

recipes.title: Maypop Jelly
recipes.description: Jelly made from wild passion fruit (maypops).

instructions.text: Combine maypops and water, then boil gently for five minutes.
Strain the mixture, discarding the pulp.
Combine the liquid with sugar and bring to a full rolling boil.
Add pectin and return to rolling boil.
Remove from heat and pour into hot, sterilized jars.
Seal the jars.

recipes.title: Day Lily Jelly
recipes.description: Floral jelly made from daylily petals.

instructions.text: Bring petals and water to a boil, then remove from heat.
Cover and let steep for 10-15 minutes.
Pour mixture through jelly bag or doubled cheesecloth into strainer.
Allow liquid to drip into bowl overnight—do not squeeze.
Measure 5 cups of juice into pot.
Add sugar, lemon juice, and pectin.
Follow standard jelly-making procedures to set.

recipes.title: Pindo Palm Jelly
recipes.description: Jelly made from pindo palm (jelly palm) fruit.

instructions.text: Cut and scrape fruit from seeds (aim for 3 cups cleaned fruit from 6 cups starting amount).
Cover fruit with 3 cups water.
Bring to boil and cook until approximately 3.5 cups infused juice remains.
Filter juice (optional for clarity).
Follow Sure Jell box recipe for three cups fruit juice.
Adjust sugar to taste and can jars.

recipes.title: Prickly Pear Cactus Jelly
recipes.description: Beautiful pink-red jelly from prickly pear cactus fruit.

instructions.text: Place fruit in large saucepan, cover with boiling water, let stand 2-3 minutes, drain.
Peel fruit, cut into pieces, cover with water and boil 5 minutes.
Pour through cheesecloth, drain thoroughly, discard seeds.
Combine juice, sugar, and lemon juice in large saucepan.
Bring to rolling boil, reduce heat to medium-high.
Add pectin, cook 8-12 minutes until thickened.
Skim foam, pour into sterilized jars.
Process in boiling water bath 5 minutes.

notes: Ripe fruit flesh tastes similar to raspberries
Eating ripe fruit can turn urine reddish (normal)

recipes.title: Juneberry Jam
recipes.description: Simple jam made with juneberries and rhubarb.

instructions.text: Grind berries and combine with sugar and rhubarb.
Bring to simmer.
Stir and cook until thick. Burns easily - watch carefully.
Pour into jars and seal.

recipes.title: Hawthorn Jelly (No-Cook Method)
recipes.description: Simple no-cook jelly from single-seed hawthorn berries.

instructions.text: Crush berries thoroughly by hand in a bowl.
Resulting liquid should be pudding-like consistency (add water if dry year).
Work quickly: squeeze seeds from berries.
Filter thick slurry into bowl.
In about five minutes, mixture will jell.
Flip onto plate; eat as-is, slice, or sun-dry.

notes: Keeps for many years when dried
Do not eat the seeds - they contain cyanide bonded with sugar (amygdalin)

recipes.title: Hawthorn Jelly (Euell Gibbons' Recipe)
recipes.attribution: Eat the Weeds - Green Deane (from Euell Gibbons)
recipes.description: Traditional cooked hawthorn jelly from the famous forager.

instructions.text: Crush fruit, add water.
Bring to boil, cover, simmer 10 minutes.
Strain through jelly bag, discard pulp/seeds/skins.
Add pectin and lemon juice if needed.
Boil 4 cups juice, add sugar.
Return to boil until perfect jelly test achieved.

notes: Do not eat the seeds - they contain cyanide bonded with sugar (amygdalin)

recipes.title: Dandelion and Burdock Syrup
recipes.description: Sweet syrup concentrate for making soft drinks.

instructions.text: Heat water and add all ingredients except sugar.
Simmer 15-20 minutes, then strain.
Dissolve sugar while hot.
To serve: Dilute with soda (1:4 ratio).
Garnish with borage flowers in summer.

recipes.title: Bulrush Flour
recipes.description: How to make flour from dried bulrush roots.

instructions.text: Clean roots thoroughly.
Dry roots completely in sun.
Remove fibers.
Pound pulp into flour. The texture depends upon how much elbow grease you use.

notes: Can be used in place of regular flour in recipes

recipes.title: Euell Gibbons' Hawthorn Jelly
recipes.description: A classic hawthorn jelly recipe from foraging legend Euell Gibbons.

instructions.text: Crush three pounds of fruit.
Add water, bring to boil, cover and simmer 10 minutes.
Strain juice through jelly bag, discard pulp and seeds.
If fruit is overripe, add pectin; add lemon juice if desired.
Place 4 cups juice in large saucepan and bring to boil.
Add 7 cups sugar and return to boil.
Test for gel consistency and jar using standard canning methods.

notes: Euell Gibbons was a famous American forager and author
Pectin may not be needed if fruit is not overripe

recipes.title: Josep Mercader's Garum
recipes.description: A modern interpretation of ancient Roman garum using olives, anchovies, and fresh herbs.

ingredients.prep_note: soaked in water 1 hour, patted dry

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a blender or food processor.
Process until light and fluffy.
Pass mixture through a food mill or push through a sieve with a wooden spoon.
Return to blender or processor and briefly process until smooth.
Refrigerate until ready to use.

notes: Use fresh herbs only - do not substitute dried
Store refrigerated

recipes.title: Quick Garum
recipes.description: A quick approximation of ancient Roman garum using grape juice and anchovy paste.

instructions.text: Cook grape juice over medium heat, reducing to one-tenth its original volume (about 3/4 cup).
Dilute anchovy paste in the concentrated juice.
Mix in a pinch of oregano.

notes: A quick substitute for traditional fermented garum
Use as a savory condiment

recipes.title: Rose Hip Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian jelly from wild rose hips
recipes.description: A delicate jelly made from wild rose hips, high in vitamin C.

instructions.text: Put rose hips in boiler with water.
Simmer until soft, then strain juice.
Let juice start simmering, add one cup sugar per cup juice.
Boil until jelly stage is reached.
Pour into jars and set in dark place to thicken.

notes: Can substitute haws (hawthorn berries) for rose hips
High in vitamin C

recipes.title: Scuppernong Preserves
recipes.description: Sweet preserves made from scuppernong grapes, a native Southern muscadine variety.

instructions.text: Cook grapes until seeds come free.
Strain through sieve or colander.
Add half cup sugar per cup juice.
Cook until mixture jellies.
Pack in hot jars and seal.

notes: For spiced preserves, add cinnamon, mace, and one cup vinegar
Scuppernongs are bronze-colored muscadine grapes native to the South

recipes.title: Hawthorn (Red Haw) Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian jelly from hawthorn berries
recipes.description: A brown-colored jelly from hawthorn berries that tastes similar to guava.

instructions.text: Simmer haws in water until soft.
Mash the berries and strain through jelly bag.
Add one pound sugar per pint of liquid plus a dash of lemon juice.
Boil until jelly stage is reached.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Results in a brown jelly tasting like guava
Haws are also called thornapples

recipes.title: Maypop Jelly
recipes.source_note: Traditional jelly from wild passionflower fruit
recipes.description: A delicate jelly made from maypops (wild passionflower fruit).

instructions.text: Use the seeds and pulp of ripe maypops.
Boil for 15 minutes in water.
Strain through jelly bag.
Add one pint sugar per pint juice.
Boil 25-30 minutes until mixture jellies.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: For syrup, boil only until thin syrup - good with biscuits or pancakes
Maypops are wild passionflower fruit native to the Southeast

recipes.title: Jerusalem Artichoke Pickle
recipes.description: A spiced pickle made from Jerusalem artichokes (sunchokes).

instructions.text: Peel artichokes and slice. Sprinkle well with salt.
Slice onions and salt them as well.
Let stand 24 hours, then wash off salt well.
Boil vinegar, sugar, and spices for 10 minutes.
Add onions and artichokes and boil 10 minutes more.
Seal in hot jars.

notes: Jerusalem artichokes are also called sunchokes
Some add horseradish instead of other spices

recipes.title: Pumpkin Butter
recipes.description: A smooth, spiced spread made from cooked pumpkin, similar to apple butter.

instructions.text: Cut and peel pumpkin.
Cook pumpkin thoroughly until very soft.
Mash until smooth.
Add sugar and cinnamon to taste.
Cook down until thick and spreadable.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Can use pie pumpkins or butternut squash
Makes excellent toast or biscuit spread

recipes.title: Quince Honey
recipes.description: A sweet preserve made from grated quinces cooked in sugar syrup.

instructions.text: Grate the quinces.
Boil sugar and water together to make syrup.
Add grated quinces to the syrup.
Boil for twenty minutes.
Seal in jars.

notes: The same method works for pear honey
Quinces must be cooked - too hard and tart to eat raw

recipes.title: Raspberry Jelly
recipes.description: A bright, flavorful jelly made from wild raspberries.

instructions.text: Boil raspberries in water until cooked.
Strain through jelly bag.
Add one pound sugar per pint of juice.
Boil until mixture sets.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Wild raspberries have more intense flavor than cultivated
Works with black or red raspberries

recipes.title: Raspberry Preserves
recipes.description: Thick preserves made from nearly-ripe raspberries.

instructions.text: Gather nearly-ripe berries.
Boil berries with water for ten minutes.
Drain off two-thirds of the juice.
Add one pound sugar per pound of berries.
Boil until thick.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Nearly-ripe berries hold their shape better
Save the drained juice for other uses

recipes.title: Blackberry Syrup
recipes.source_note: Traditional spiced blackberry syrup for pancakes
recipes.description: A spiced syrup made from blackberry juice, perfect for pancakes.

instructions.text: Cook blackberries and strain to get juice.
Mix juice with sugar and all spices.
Boil for 15 minutes.
Pour into bottles and seal.
Serve over pancakes.

notes: Adjust spices to taste
Also good over waffles or ice cream

recipes.title: Huckleberry Jam
recipes.description: A thick, flavorful jam made from wild huckleberries.

instructions.text: Wash berries and place in pot with water.
Boil until very tender.
Add half pound sugar per pound fruit.
Boil 30 minutes until thick.
Pour into jars and seal.

notes: Huckleberries are found in mountain forests
Jam thickens more as it cools

recipes.title: Fig Preserves
recipes.description: Sweet whole fig preserves, a Southern delicacy.

instructions.text: Wash figs and pat dry.
Bring sugar and water to a boil, add figs.
Cook slowly until tender, let stand overnight.
Day 2: Drain syrup, boil again, pour over figs, stand overnight.
Day 3: Cook figs in syrup until clear, add lemon juice.
Pack in jars and process 30 minutes in hot water bath.

notes: The multi-day process keeps figs whole and plump
Use firm ripe figs for best results

recipes.title: Wild Grape Jelly
recipes.description: A flavorful jelly made from wild grapes with a hint of vinegar.

instructions.text: Wash grapes and remove stems.
Crush grapes in large pan.
Add vinegar and cinnamon if desired.
Cook slowly 15 minutes, then strain through cheesecloth.
Boil juice 20 minutes, add sugar.
Cook until starts to jell, pour into jars.

notes: Fox grapes, possum grapes, or muscadines all work
The vinegar adds brightness and helps preserve

recipes.title: Spiced Wild Grapes
recipes.description: Wild grapes preserved in a sweet, spiced vinegar syrup.

instructions.text: Wash and stem grapes.
Pulp grapes (squeeze pulp from skins).
Put pulp with seeds over fire, cook until seeds come free.
Add skins and pulp with sugar, vinegar, and spices.
Cook until thick.
Can while hot.

notes: Pulping separates the skins from the seedy centers
Excellent with game meats

recipes.title: Muscadine Jelly
recipes.description: A classic Southern jelly made from half-ripe muscadine grapes.

instructions.text: Take pulp and juice of half-ripe muscadines.
Nearly cover with water and boil few minutes.
Strain through jelly bag.
Measure juice and add one pound white sugar per pint juice.
Boil until congeals when dropped on cold dry surface (20-30 minutes).

notes: Half-ripe grapes have more pectin for better jelling
Test by dropping on cold plate

recipes.title: Cranberry Sauce
recipes.description: A simple two-ingredient cranberry sauce.

instructions.text: Wash berries.
Add sugar to berries, stirring thoroughly.
Cook slowly without additional water (just what remains from washing).
Boil for 10 minutes.

notes: No additional water needed - the washing water is sufficient

recipes.title: Spiced Cranberries
recipes.description: Tangy spiced cranberries preserved in vinegar with warm spices.

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a large pot.
Boil for 2 hours.
Place in hot sterilized jars and seal.

notes: For canning - use proper canning procedures

recipes.title: Cranberry Orange Relish
recipes.description: A fresh, no-cook cranberry orange relish.

instructions.text: Put berries and oranges (including rind) through food grinder using coarse blade.
Stir in sugar.
Chill before serving.

notes: Keeps several weeks refrigerated
Include the orange rind for best flavor

recipes.title: Cranberry Salsa
recipes.description: A unique cranberry salsa with cilantro, jalapeño, and lime.

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in food processor fitted with medium blade.
Chop to medium consistency.
Refrigerate if not using immediately.
Serve at room temperature.

notes: Great with tortilla chips or as a topping for turkey

recipes.title: Jerusalem Artichoke Pickles
recipes.description: Pickled sunchokes using bread and butter pickle method.

instructions.text: Clean tubers thoroughly - they are lumpy and tedious.
Slice tubers.
Pickle using bread and butter style method (works better than dill).

notes: Pick tubers two weeks after flowers fade
Flavor improves after frost
Don't store except in ground - dig as needed
Build digestive tolerance by eating small portions for 3-4 days first

recipes.title: Pickled Pig's Feet
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Tangy preserved pig's feet in spiced brine.

instructions.text: Cover pig's feet with salted water; simmer 3-4 hours until tender.
Remove feet and pack into clean jars.
Boil vinegar, water, and spices together.
Pour hot brine over feet in jars.
Seal and refrigerate at least 1 week before eating.

notes: A traditional way to preserve meat without refrigeration
